AI_QUALITY_FAILURES.reasoning: There is strong evidence that bot-driven analysis and messaging misled the case, including an explicitly identified hallucination about segfaults/crashes that later had to be retracted. Customer also perceived the responses as generic/bot-like (“time-kill mode”), indicating AI output degraded trust and clarity.
evidence: Engineering: “The above statement appears to be a hallucination. There is 0 evidence of any crashes in the log analysis output from what I can tell.”
Engineering: “There are two bots at play here... This is the root of the confusion here:” (re: the segfault/collectord crash claim)
Agent to customer: “After reviewing the logs again, the initial diagnosis was incorrect.”
Customer: “So many responses from your replies are saying \"feedback and the information you have shared will be carefully reviewed...\" Is this so-called support still operated by the ChatBot?”

AI_WALL_LOOPING.reasoning: Customer requested a live agent and the interaction did progress into a ticket/handover; the main failure was delay/handling, not repeated AI loops asking the same questions or preventing escalation.
evidence: Customer: “Yes, I request a live agent transfer in this chat,”
Customer: “Button selection: [💬 Chat with live agent]”

IGNORING_CONTEXT.reasoning: Support asked for information the customer had already provided at ticket creation (reason for upgrade / prior issues). The initial issue description clearly states URL categorization problems pre-upgrade, yet later support re-asks this context instead of acknowledging it.
evidence: Initial issue description: “experiencing specific issues with URL catagorisation” + “most URLs not being categorized”
Agent later: “Prior to the upgrade, were you experiencing issues? Is this why you performed the upgrade?”
Customer response calling this out: “Prior to the upgrade, I was experiencing issues with URL categorization. Most of the connections show unclassified...”

RESPONSE_DELAYS.reasoning: Customer reported a critical case with no response for ~24 hours and repeatedly followed up due to lack of engagement. Even if under 3 calendar days, the ticket contains explicit customer complaints about waiting and lack of timely response, which materially harmed the experience.
evidence: Customer: “The case was raised in Critical Priority, and no show for 24 hours.”
Timeline gap: customer provided details 2025-10-30 09:13, first substantive human public response appears 2025-10-31 14:34 (~29 hours later).
Customer follow-ups during wait: “Can someone take it on a serious note, OR is your support also in AI time-kill mode?”

PREMATURE_CLOSURE.reasoning: The ticket thread provided does not show closure of the customer-facing ticket while unresolved (it remains active with continued customer responses).

P1_SEV1_MISHANDLING.reasoning: Customer described a business-critical, critical-priority situation (CPU pegged/high alarms) yet experienced a ~24-hour lack of response. Additionally, the system/bot action placed the case on hold for an extreme duration (“9999 hour(s)”), which is incompatible with P1 handling and signals process breakdown.
evidence: ATLAS transcript: “It's business critical & needs human support intervention”
Customer: “The case was raised in Critical Priority, and no show for 24 hours.”
Automation: “Centralsupport-ai-acc commented privately: Placing on hold for 9999 hour(s)”
